Authors: Sigisfredo Garnica, Pablo Sandoval-Leiva, Kai Riess
Title:
Phylogenetic relationships in the genus Podoserpula and
description of P. aliweni, a new species from Chile
Keywords:
ITS, nuc 28S, rpb1, Amylocorticiales, pagoda fungus,
southern beech, Chilean mycobiota, 1 new taxon
Abstract:
The phylogenetic relationships of pagoda fungus
(Podoserpula, Amylocorticiales) were inferred from nuc rDNA
ITS1-5.8S-ITS2 (ITS) sequences of specimens sampled in Australia, Chile,
China, Madagascar, and New Zealand. Podoserpula was divided into two
major lineages: Clade A containing Australian and New Zealand
collections designated P. pusio and the Chinese species P.
ailaoshanensis, which have basidiospores with no reaction to Melzers
reagent; and Clade B, which includes a species described from Chile, P.
aliweni, and specimens originating from Australia, Chile, Madagascar,
and New Zealand with dextrinoid basidiospores. Podoserpula aliweni forms
a unique branch in the phylogenetic tree and differs from its most
closely related taxon by 1.8 to 2.1% in the ITS region. The new species
exhibits a treelike habit with a white to concolourous stipe-like base
with the hymenophores main subcylindrical axis bearing up to 18
superimposed pilei, slightly enrolled white margins shading from
yellowish-white to orange-yellow towards the center, and ellipsoid to
broadly ellipsoid basidiospores measuring 4.24.7 × 3.33.6 µm.
Ecologically, P. aliweni grows during the rainy season, often
gregariously on dried branches or wet soil under Nothofagus obliqua and
N. dombeyi and has a distribution range of more than 600 km in southern
Chile. Our study contributes with 14 new ITS sequences, extends the
known distributional range, and also increases our knowledge on the
phylogenetic diversity and taxonomy in Podoserpula.
